Page URL Accessibility Score Issues Actions
Front page https://blogs.library.columbia.edu/journalism 88 3

Image elements do not have <code>[alt]</code> attributes

Informative elements should aim for short, descriptive alternate text. Decorative elements can be ignored with an empty alt attribute. Learn more about the <code>alt</code> attribute.

Links rely on color to be distinguishable.

Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. Link text that is discernible improves the experience for users with low vision. Learn how to make links distinguishable.

Links do not have a discernible name

Link text (and alternate text for images, when used as links) that is discernible, unique, and focusable improves the navigation experience for screen reader users. Learn how to make links accessible.
Front page https://blogs.library.columbia.edu/ 92 2

Links rely on color to be distinguishable.

Low-contrast text is difficult or impossible for many users to read. Link text that is discernible improves the experience for users with low vision. Learn how to make links distinguishable.

Touch targets do not have sufficient size or spacing.

Touch targets with sufficient size and spacing help users who may have difficulty targeting small controls to activate the targets. Learn more about touch targets.

Front page https://blogs.library.columbia.edu/clio/ 97 1

<code><frame></code> or <code><iframe></code> elements do not have a title

Screen reader users rely on frame titles to describe the contents of frames. Learn more about frame titles.
